{{Infobox radio station | name = DR P2 | image = DR P2 logo 2013.png | image_size = 250px | alt = | caption = | city = | area = [[Denmark]] | branding = | slogan = | frequency = | translator = | repeater = | airdate = {{Start date and age|1951|}} | last airdate = <!-- for defunct stations --> | share = | share as of = | share source = | format = [[Classical music|Classical]] | language = [[Danish language|Danish]] | power = | erp = | haat = | class = | facility_id = | coordinates = | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = | former_frequencies = | affiliations = | operator = [[DR (broadcaster)|DR]] | owner = [[DR (broadcaster)|DR]] | licensee = | sister_stations = | webcast = *[https://www.dr.dk/radio/live/p2/ Web Stream] '''HTTP progressive Streams''' *[http://live-icy.gss.dr.dk/A/A04L.mp3.m3u (Shoutcast, 92 Kbps MP3)] *[http://live-icy.gss.dr.dk/A/A04H.mp3.m3u (Shoutcast, 192 Kbps MP3)] '''HLS Streams''' *[http://drradio2-lh.akamaihd.net/i/p2_9@143504/master.m3u8 (192 Kbps AAC)] | website = {{URL|https://www.dr.dk/p2}} }} '''DR P2''' – in Denmark normally referred to as simply '''P2''' – is a Danish [[radio broadcasting|radio station]] operated by the [[DR (broadcaster)|Danish Broadcasting Corporation]]. It specializes in classical music, both recorded and in live performance, as well as reporting on and providing discussion of the classical music scene.
Since 1991 P2 has organized a [[chamber music]] competition for promising young musicians, held every 2 years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kammermusik live og i radioen|url=http://www.musikeren.dk/nyheder/nyhed/artikel/p2_kammermusikkonkurrence_live_og_i_radioen/|accessdate=6 April 2017|publisher=Musikeren|date=22 February 2011}}</ref>
==History== On 1 October 1951 the then ''Statsradiofonien'' launched their second radio station, called ''Program 2''.<ref>{{cite web|title=DANMARKS RADIO 1925-|url=http://danmarkshistorien.dk/leksikon-og-kilder/vis/materiale/danmarks-radio-1925/|website=Danmarkshistorien.dk|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref> In 1959 Statsradiofonien changed its name to '''Danmarks Radio''', and to '''DR''' in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|title=TIDSLINJE: Fra Statsradiofonien til DR|url=http://www.billedbladet.dk/kendte/danmark/tv/dr/tidslinje-fra-statsradiofonien-til-dr|website=Billedbladet.dk|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref>
In 1960 Danmarks Radio started regional programming on P2 in the evenings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dansk radio historie|url=http://danskradio.dk/historien.html|website=Dansk Radio|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref> The station switched to nationwide stereo output on 1 October 1969 after some regional trials. Classical music was first broadcast on the station in 1980 during the evenings when the regional programming took over the daytime schedule.
DR had in 2001 won the rights to use Denmark's new fourth nationwide FM channel to which the station was moved and re-launched as DR P2 Musik & Kultur on 1 September 2001.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nielsen|first1=Stig Hartvig|title=I dag starter Danmarks nye 4. lands-dækkende FM kanal: "P2 Musik & Kultur"|url=http://www.radionytarkiv.dk/artikel/default.asp?id=2808|accessdate=6 April 2017|publisher=radionyt.com|date=1 September 2001}}</ref> The regional programming stayed on the former P2 regional channels and was re-launched as [[DR P4]].
DR subsequently lost the rights to continue the use of the fourth nationwide FM channel from 2011, which meant DR only had room for three of their four FM channels. DR therefore decided that [[DR P1|P1]] and P2 must share the nationwide FM channel that P1 had been using, starting on 1 November 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=P2 flytter ind hos P1 på FM|url=https://www.dr.dk/presse/p2-flytter-ind-hos-p1-paa-fm|accessdate=6 April 2017|publisher=DR|date=6 October 2011}}</ref> On the same day DR P2 became ''DR P2 Klassisk''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meget mindre klassisk musik på DR fra 1. november|url=http://www.radionytarkiv.dk/artikel/default.asp?id=18753|accessdate=6 April 2017|publisher=radionyt.com|date=25 October 2011}}</ref> Both channels continued as two separate channels digitally on [[Digital audio broadcasting|DAB]] and [[Internet radio|online]].<ref>{{cite news|title=P1 og P2 fortsætter som digital radio|url=http://www.dr.dk/Temaer/digitalradio/artikler/20120305204950.htm|accessdate=6 April 2017|publisher=DR|date=9 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2013 DR P2 Klassisk changed name to its current name DR P2.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hvor er DR P2 Klassisk blevet af?|url=http://www.dr.dk/Om_DR/Kontakt+DR/Spoergsmaal+og+svar/Radio/20130403110250.htm|publisher=DR|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref>
On 1 October 2017 P2 became available on [[Digital_audio_broadcasting#DAB.2B_2|DAB+]] radio when a nationwide switch-over took place.<ref>{{cite news|title=Overgangen til DAB+ udsat til 1. oktober 2017|url=http://danskemedier.dk/nyhed/overgangen-til-dab-udsat-til-1-oktober-2017/|accessdate=8 April 2017|agency=Danske Medier|date=18 May 2016}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox newspaper | name = Die Matie | logo = [[File:Die Matie (S.A).gif|240px|Die Matie Logo]] | image = | caption = | type = Biweekly | foundation = {{Start date|1941|08|1}} | circulation = 8000 | website = {{URL|http://www.diematie.com}} }} '''Die Matie''' is a student newspaper at the [[University of Stellenbosch]]. Founded in 1941, '''Die Matie''' is published every second Wednesday during the academic term. The editorial content includes sections on news, student life, sport, arts and entertainment, current affairs and news from other campuses. The entire production of '''Die Matie''' – from photos, articles and advertisements to page layout and distribution – is managed by the editorial staff; all students. == History == On August 1, 1941, the first issue of '''Die Matie''' student newspaper was published in Stellenbosch. == Distribution == 8,000 copies of the newspaper are distributed on the main campus of Stellenbosch, as well as on the three satellite campuses, the medical campus at [[Tygerberg]], military campus at [[Saldanha Bay|Saldanha]] and business school in [[Bellville, Western Cape|Bellville]]. '''Die Matie''' has an estimated readership of 16 000 students, staff and Stellenbosch residents. In addition to print the paper is also published electronically though an online archive. == Structure == With every edition of '''Die Matie''' a pre-elected editorial team member has the responsibility of compiling a supplement, either on: motoring, lifestyle, travel, science & technology and health. The editor of this supplement is expected to gather advertisements for the supplement (as ads pay for the printing of the supplement), the collection of editorial content, photos and for the layout of the supplement. == Financing == Although '''Die Matie''' receives a small subsidy from Stellenbosch University's Student Affairs Department, all printing costs and some of the office upkeep is covered by advertisements, which are the responsibility of '''Die Matie''''s advertising manager (also a student and member of the editorial team). ==See also== * [[List of newspapers in South Africa]] == External links == * [http://www.diematie.com Official Homepage] * [http://www.sun.ac.za/diematie Official Online Archive] * [http://www.sun.ac.za Stellenbosch University Homepage] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120723113852/https://www.stellenboschsr.co.za/ Student Representative Council] * [http://academic.sun.ac.za/journalism/sji/1995/matie.htm The full history] {{af icon}}
{{Stellenbosch University}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Matie}} [[Category:Student newspapers published in South Africa]] [[Category:Stellenbosch University]] [[Category:Afrikaans-language newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Stellenbosch]] [[Category:1941 establishments in South Africa]] {{SouthAfrica-newspaper-stub}}

[[File:ET Addis asv2018-02 img5.jpg|thumb|A [[post box]] in [[Addis Ababa]]]] '''Ethiopian Postal Service''' ('''Ethio Postal''') is the national [[mail|postal service]] of [[Ethiopia]].
== Objective == The purpose of the Ethio Postal is to allow a portal for mail acceptance, transfer deliveries and other postal services for its customers. The act of allowing these services to take place initially started as a need for the Ethiopian people to communicate on a nationwide scale. Ethiopian Postal Service was created by Law with the view to establish and promote [[Mail|Postal Services]] based on the development.
== Audience == * The [[general public]] * Embassies consulates * [[International organisations in Africa|International Organizations]]
==External links == *[http://www.ethiopostal.com/ Official website] *[http://www.ethiopostal.com/index.php/ems Ethio Postal Service] *[http://pe.usps.com/text/Imm/ce_031.htm How to mail to Ethiopia] *[http://www.ethiopostal.com/index.php/history General Information about Ethiopian Postal Service History]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Heart Series 2 | image = | genre = Teen drama | writer = | starring = [[Yuki Kato (actor)|Yuki Kato]] {{br}} Adipati Dolken {{br}} Pamela Bowie {{br}} Sahila Hisyam {{br}} Aditya Suryo {{br}} [[Kevin Julio]] | picture_format = ([[Standard definition television|SDTV]]) | runtime = 60 minutes | director = Sony Gaokasak | opentheme = ''My Heart'' by [[Acha Septriasa]] & [[Irwansyah]] | endtheme = ''My Heart'', [[Acha Septriasa]] & [[Irwansyah]] | distributor = [[SinemArt]] | company = | creator = [[Starvisison]] | producer = [[Leo Sutanto]] | country = [[Indonesia]] | location = [[Jakarta]] | slogan = | language = [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] | network = [[SCTV (Indonesia)|SCTV]] | first_run = {{Start date|2013|3|25}} | first_aired = {{Start date|2013|3|25}} | last_aired = July 5, 2013 | preceded_by = | seasons = | num_episodes = | website = }} '''''Heart Series 2''''' is a [[soap opera]] which aired on [[SCTV (Indonesia)|SCTV]]. The show is produced by Servia. Players such as [[Yuki Kato (actor)|Yuki Kato]], Adipati Dolken, Pamela Bowie, Sahila Hisham, Aditya Suryo and [[Kevin Julio]].
==Cast== * [[Yuki Kato (actress)|Yuki Kato]] as Rachel * [[Olivia Jensen]] as Olivia * [[Adipati Dolken]] as Fahrel * [[Pamela Bowie]] as Luna * [[Unique Priscilla]] as Rahayu * [[Astri Nurdin]] as Marissa * [[Ponco Buwono]] as Yuda * [[Ikang Fauzi]] as Adam * [[Sylvia Fully]] as Sarah * [[Sahila Hisyam]] as Vandra * [[Vanessa Angel (Indonesian actress)|Vanessa Angel]] as Yunita * [[Kevin Julio]] as Boy
==History== The band "The Rocketz" played in a school event. Farel member band (Adipati Dolken), Bevan (Aditya Suryo) and Endo (Joshua Otay) managed to make their high school female students in hysterics at his appearance. When finished performing, the girls scramble to give gifts to the band. However, the manager, Rachel (Yuki Kato), only allowing the students to give gifts to Bevan and Endo. Farel who feel that they are the ones who are idolized was puzzled why he did not get a gift at all.
Farel, Rachel, Bevan and Endo briefly as four people who were good friends like friends. Rachel likes Farel since they are friends from childhood. But Farel was never aware of it. Likewise with the ignorant and slengekan Endo. Bevan's just the start feeling suspicious of Rachel on Farel.
Meanwhile, the figure Vandra (Sahila Hisham), a beautiful girl, rich and sexy at the school, was jealous of Rachel ever closer to Farel. Though Bevan and Endo infatuated with Vandra. Vandra like Farel. Farel did not like her. Vandra including the arrogant and cocky girls pretty antagonistic.
On the other hand, Luna (Pamela Bowie) forced to live in Singapore with his father, Adam (Ikang Fawzi), for treatment. Luna always secretly monitor Farel through YouTube, Twitter or Facebook. Farel himself did not realize that Luna was still watching him from across the country. When returning to Indonesia, he has a homeschooling teacher named Mrs. Sarah (Sylvia Fully) Adam preferred.
Suddenly, there came home that Rachel is his own father and his own twin sister Olivia (Olivia Jensen), Rachel fell off a cliff and was hospitalized, while Luna was in need of a donor liver, Rachel heart it was donate her heart to Luna, as Rachel Farel and Luna would like to see happy. Rachel not died and was replaced by his twin sister is Olivia. Olivia wants to continue the desire to unify Farel and Rachel,Luna

page.title: International Year for People of African Descent

revision.text:
The [[United Nations General Assembly]] declared the year 2011 as '''International Year for People of African Descent''' (in UN resolution A/RES/64/169).<ref name=UNCHR>[http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/IntlYearPeopleAfricanDescent.aspx 2011 International Year for People of African Descent"], UNCHR,</ref> That year also marked the 10th anniversary of the [[World Conference against Racism 2001|World Conference Against Racism]] (also known as the Durban Conference),<ref name=Dialogue>[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/culture/themes/dynamic-content-single-view/news/history_in_dialogue_on_memories_of_the_slave_trade_and_slavery/#.VWcGgc9Viko "History in dialogue on memories of the slave trade and slavery"], UNESCO, August 22, 2011.</ref> which approved a resolution stating that slavery along with the colonization that sustained it were crimes against humanity.<ref>Gina Thésée and Paul R. Carr, [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Paul_Carr/publication/265602678_The_2011_International_Year_for_People_of_African_Descent_(IYPAD)_The_paradox_of_colonized_invisibility_within_the_promise_of_mainstream_visibility/links/54165ad90cf2bb7347db47fb.pdf "The 2011 International Year for People of African Descent (IYPAD): The paradox of colonized invisibility within the promise of mainstream visibility"], ''Decolonization: Indigeneity, Education & Society'', Vol. 1, No. 1, 2012, pp. 158-180.</ref>
==Selected related initiatives== The [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|United Nations High Commission for Human Rights]] coordinated activities surrounding the Year, and encouraged other parties, both UN agencies as well as member states, to carry out similar initiatives.<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/culture/themes/dialogue/the-slave-route/right-box/related-information/2011-international-year-for-people-of-african-descent/ "Culture: 2011, International Year for People of African Descent"], UNESCO.</ref><ref name=Dialogue /> These included:<ref>[http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/IYPADCalendarEvents.aspx "Calendar of events"], 2011 International Year for People of African Descent, United Nations Human Rights.</ref>
* February: ''Islands as Crossroads: Sustaining Cultural Diversity in Small Island Developing States'' (publication)<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/natural-sciences/priority-areas/sids/single-view-small-island/news/just_published_islands_as_crossroads_sustaining_cultural_diversity_in_small_island_developing_states/#.VWcG2s9Viko "Small Island Developing States: Just published: Islands as Crossroads - Sustaining Cultural Diversity in Small Island Developing States"], UNESCO.</ref> * February 4–24: Exhibition on Arts and Poetry by artist Hilda Zagaglia, Alta Garcia, [[Argentina]] * February 28–March 3: Meeting of the International Scientific Committee of the [[UNESCO]] [[The Slave Route Project|Slave Route Project]], [[Bogota]] * March 21–23: SEPHIS Workshop "Equity, Justice, Development: People of African Descent in Latin America in comparative Perspective", [[University of Cartagena]], [[Colombia]]<ref>[http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Events/IYPAD/Prog_Cartagena_Colombia_21-23_March.pdf "Equity, Justice, Development: People of African Descent in Latin America in comparative Perspective"], Cartagena, Colombia, March 21 to 23, 2011.</ref> * April: Launching of the international Year for People of African Descent in [[Brazil]], UNESCO [[Brasilia]] * May 4–11: Black International Cinema Festival, Fountainhead Tanz Theatre, [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] * May 10: Commemorating the Slave Trade and Slavery as a Crime against Humanity, France * June 6–12: Afro-Brazilian Arts and Cultural Heritage Festival, [[Washington DC]], [[United States of America]]<ref>[http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Events/IYPAD/AfroBrazilFestival2011.pdf "Afro-Brazilian Arts and Cultural Heritage Festival Brings Music, Art, Dance, Film, and Food to Nation's Capital"], CapoeiraDC Press release.</ref> * July 4–15: Harriet Tubman Student Summer Programme on "Introduction to African and African Diaspora Studies", [[York University, Toronto]], [[Canada]] * August 11–13: Pan-African Women's Action Summit, [[Minneapolis Community and Technical College]], [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]], US * August 23: [[International Day for the Remembrance of the Slave Trade and its Abolition]] ** [[Angola]]: Conference "Escravos angolanos povoaram tambem as Antilhas Neerlandesas" ("Angolan slaves also populated the [[Netherlands Antilles]]"), organized by the Eduardo dos Santos Foundation, at the [[Agostinho Neto University]] in [[Luanda]] ** [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] (DRC): Workshop on achievements of the Slave Route Project in the DRC, with presentation of ''The Slave Trade, Slavery and Colonial Violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo'' (published 2010) ** [[Ghana]]: Workshop on the slave trade for educators from three regions of the world, [[Accra]]<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/media-services/single-view/news/23_august_teachers_from_three_regions_learn_lessons_about_the_slave_trade/#.VWevVs9Viko "23 August: Teachers from three regions learn lessons about the slave trade"], UNESCO.</ref> ** [[Grenada]]: exhibition and commemorative activities organized by National Commission for UNESCO and the National Museum of Grenada, [[St. George's, Grenada|St. George's]] ** [[Madagascar]]: screening of the documentary ''Slave Routes: A Global Vision'', at the [[University of Antananarivo]] ** [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]]: launch of the activities of the national committee for the Slave Route Project<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/culture/themes/dynamic-content-single-view/news/unesco_slave_route_project_launched_in_saint_kitts_and_nevis/#.VWezQ89Viko "UNESCO Slave Route project Launched in Saint Kitts and Nevis"], UNESCO.</ref> ** [[Senegal]]: Panel discussion, painting and photo exhibition, cultural and artistic activities at the Joseph Ndiaye Socio-cultural Centre, [[Gorée]]<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/culture/themes/dynamic-content-single-view/news/retour_a_goree_souvenir_de_la_traite_negriere_et_de_son_abolition/#.VWex-s9Viko "Return to Gorée: Remembrance of the Slave Trade and of its Abolition"], UNESCO.</ref> ** [[UK]]: Commemoration at the [[National Maritime Museum]], [[London]] * September 22–24: 7th International African Diaspora Heritage Trail Conference, World Trade and Convention Centre, [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]], Canada * October: [[Boscoe Holder]] exhibition at the Upper Room Art Gallery at Top of the Mount, [[Mount St Benedict]], [[St Augustine, Trinidad]]<ref>[http://www.trinidadexpress.com/sunday-mix/Discovering_The_Art_Of_Boscoe_Holder-131928693.html "Discovering the Art of Boscoe Holder"], ''Trinidad Express Newspapers'', 15 October 2011.</ref> * October 20: Panel discussion "The Causes and Consequences of Racism", [[Eastern Michigan University]], [[Ypsilanti, Michigan]], US<ref>[http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Events/IYPAD/20October_PanelDiscussion_MichiganUSA.pdf "The Causes and Consequences of Racism"], EMU Department of African American Studies.</ref> * October 29: Celebration of the International Year for People of African Descent and Promotion of the General History of Africa, UNESCO, [[Paris]] * November 2 (–June 24, 2012): Itinerant photographic exhibition: "Women in Africa - No Color One Color", Italian Institute of Culture, [[Nairobi, Kenya]]; Sheraton Hotel, [[Milan Malpensa Airport]], Italy; and other venues<ref>[http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Events/IYPAD/c_stampa_WoMeninAfricaLMGilberti.pdf International Itinerant Photographic Exhibition “WoMen in Africa – NO COLOR ONE COLOR” by Ludovico Maria Gilberti], Fuoriserrone.</ref> * November 9: Celebration – International Year for People of African Descent; Africa, Mère de tous les peuples. Palais des Nations, [[Geneva, Switzerland]]<ref>[http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/Events/IYPAD/Mere_tous_peuples_9Nov2011.pdf Celebration - Africa...Mère de tous les peuples"], une Célébration, 9 November 2011.</ref> * Brazil-Africa: Crossed Histories Programme in the 36th UNESCO General Conference
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==See also== *[[International Decade for People of African Descent]] (2015–2024)
==External links== * [http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/IntlYearPeopleAfricanDescent.aspx Official website]
{{UN International Years}}

[[File:Op het trottoiron the sidewalk.jpg|thumb|220px|Muslim women riding traditional bicycles as this one are seen as immodest]]
The proper '''Islamic bicycle''' for the [[Women in Islam|Muslim women]] is a topic of heated discussion in both [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] and [[Shia Islam|Shia]] Islam. Concerns centre around [[Modesty#Islamic modesty|modesty]] (not revealing the body) and mobility (social control).
Theologian and philosopher Alparslan Acikgenc addressed the issue in a conference in [[Istanbul]], saying "a bicycle that is produced with God’s blessings in mind and man’s interests at its fore is an Islamic bicycle". Secular academics worry that [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|Turkey’s Islamist government]] is putting [[Islamic attitudes towards science|Islam ahead of science]]. Turkish journalist [[Mustafa Akyol]] argues that the very idea of an Islamic bicycle is indicative of a "mentality that has stagnated Muslim thought".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21562945|title=Peddling religion: Why secular academics fret about an “Islamic bicycle”|date=Sep 15, 2012|newspaper=The Economist}}</ref> [[Women%27s_rights_in_Saudi_Arabia#Mobility|Saudi Arabia bans the use of bicycles by women]] except in restricted recreational areas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://world.time.com/2013/04/03/saudi-women-can-now-ride-bicycles-in-public-kind-of/|title=Saudi Women Can Now Ride Bicycles in Public (Kind of)|date=April 3, 2013|work=Time Magazine|author=Kristene Quan}}</ref> The Iranian version of the bicycle has a “boxy contraption that hides a woman’s lower body.”<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/09/weekinreview/09slackman.html|title=Molding the Ideal Islamic Citizen|date=Sep 9, 2007|author=Michael Slackman|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> In Iran it is forbidden for women to ride traditional bicycles out of concerns for [[Modesty#Islamic modesty|modesty]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Theodoulou |title=Women cyclists face jail, warns Iranian police chief |url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/middle-east/women-cyclists-face-jail-warns-iranian-police-chief |work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)]] |date=24 October 2010 |accessdate=8 March 2014 }}</ref> Women riders are attacked by [[vigilante]]s.
Critics condemn both the bicycle ban and the Islamic bicycle as tools of oppression.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/opinion/2007-06-28-iranian-bicycle-women_N.htm|title='Islamic bicycle' can't slow Iranian women|author=Farzaneh Milani|date=Jun 28, 2007|newspaper=USA Today}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/2016/10/25/womans-right-bike-iranian-women-rebelling-cycle-ban/|title=A Woman’s Right to Bike|date=October 25, 2016|work=Ms. Magazine|author=Sophie Lloyd}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Outline of cycling]] *[[Bicycling and feminism]] *[[History_of_the_bicycle#The_bicycle_craze]] *[[Victorian dress reform]] for a discussion of "rational dress"
==References== {{Reflist}}

List of World Heritage sites in Western Asia

revision.text:
The [[UNESCO]] (United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization) has designated 82 [[World Heritage site]]s in 18 countries (also called "[[Sovereign state|state parties]]") of [[Western Asia]]: [[Armenia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Bahrain]], [[Cyprus]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Iran]], [[Iraq]], [[Israel]], [[Jordan]], [[Lebanon]], [[Oman]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Syria]], [[Turkey]], [[United Arab Emirates]], [[Qatar]] and [[Yemen]]. While [[Egypt]] is partially in Western Asia, its World Heritage sites are listed under [[List of World Heritage sites in Africa|Africa]] instead. One site is located in [[Jerusalem]].Site proposed by [[Jordan]]. UNESCO has stated that "In line with relevant UN resolutions, [[East Jerusalem]] remains part of the occupied Palestinian territory, and the status of Jerusalem must be resolved in permanent status negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians." [[Kuwait]] is the only country in the region that does not have any World Heritage sites.{{Cite web|title=Number of World Heritage Properties by region |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/stat#s1 |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}}{{cite web|url= http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm#europe|title= Composition of macro geographical (continental) regions, geographical sub-regions, and selected economic and other groupings|year= 2010|work= Geographical region and composition of each region|publisher= [[United Nations Statistics Division]]|accessdate= 20 October 2011}} [[Arabian Oryx Sanctuary]] was designated as a World Heritage site of Oman in 1994 but was [[Former UNESCO World Heritage sites|delisted]] in 2007. As the protected area was reduced by 90% as a result of Oman's decision, UNESCO delisted the site.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/654 Arabian Oryx Sanctuary], UNESCO In this region, [[Iran]] is home to the most inscribed sites with 23 sites.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list |title=World Heritage List |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=23 June 2014}} The first sites to be recognized by UNESCO from the region were [[Persepolis]], [[Meidan Emam, Esfahan]], [[Tchogha Zanbil]] (Iran) and the [[Ancient City of Damascus]] (Syria).{{Cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&l=en&action=stat&mode=table#s4 |title=Number of World Heritage properties inscribed each Year |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=8 September 2011}} Each year, UNESCO's [[World Heritage Committee]] may inscribe new sites on the list, or delist sites that no longer meet the criteria. Selection is based on [[World Heritage site#Selection criteria|ten criteria]]: six for [[cultural heritage]] (i–vi) and four for [[natural heritage]] (vii–x).{{Cite web|title=The Criteria for Selection |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=10 September 2011}} Some sites, designated "mixed sites," represent both cultural and natural heritage. In Western Asia, there are 67 cultural, 1 natural, and 3 mixed sites.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/nominations/ |title=World Heritage List Nominations |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} The World Heritage Committee may also specify that a site is [[World Heritage in Danger|endangered]], citing "conditions which threaten the very characteristics for which a property was inscribed on the World Heritage List." Seven sites in this region are currently listed as endangered; one site ([[Bahla Fort]]) had been listed previously, and possible danger listing has been considered by UNESCO in a number of other cases.{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/158/ |title=World Heritage in Danger |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=28 May 2010}} ==Legend== The table is sortable by column by clicking on the [[File:Sort both.gif]] at the top of the appropriate column; alphanumerically for the site, area, and year columns; by state party for the location column; and by criteria type for the criteria column. If available, the size of the buffer zone has been noted as well. [[Thuần Việt]] | released = {{Film date|2009}} | runtime = 10 minutes x 55 episodes | country = Vietnam | language = Vietnamese | budget = | gross =}} '''Lu and Bun''' ({{lang-vi|Lu và Bun}}) is a 2009 Vietnamese [[computer-animated]] comedy-adventure television series produced by [[Vietkite Media]]. ==Plot== Lion Lu and rabbit Bun were friends, but they have characters and favourites which were different each other. So, there're many funny and dramatic situations which happened. ==External links== * [http://tuoitre.vn/Van-hoa-Giai-tri/Dien-anh/319585/Hoat-hinh-VN-se-tinh-giac.html Director Phùng Văn Hà : Vietnamese animation'll get up] - ''Tuổi Trẻ Online'' // Webnesday, June 3, 2009 (08:13 ~ [[UTC+7]]) [[Category:Vietnamese computer-animated films]] [[Category:Vietnamese animated television series]] {{animation-tv-prog-stub}} {{Vietnam-tv-stub}}

'''Luotes''' are magic words of Finnish [[Kalevala meter]]ic [[incantation]]. Possibly luotes have been needed only for the most powerful spells, in which case they have denoted especially [[holy]] words. Different incantations have been distinct luotes, which have been must a command of to be able to the incantation.
Finnish-language word "luote" contains possibly a verb trust, in [[Finnish language|Finnish]] "luottaa", that have evidently referred to it, that the words have been trusted or given up only from a seer for a close relative for a student or from a dead or a spirit for a seer. ("Give up" is in [[Finnish language|Finnish]] "luovuttaa", which is a cognate word to the above-mentioned Finnish-language word "luottaa", in [[English language|English]] "to trust".)
Missing luotes have been must fetch in folk stories including from [[Tuonela]], [[Louhi]] or buried [[Giant (mythology)|giant]] [[Antero Vipunen]].
==See also== *[[incantation]]

Each episode is presented as a moment in "Howard history" and is presented by the fictional British character, Sir Hardin Thicke, voiced by voice-over actor [[Mike Pollock (voice actor)|Mike Pollock]].https://soundcloud.com/itsamike/mike-pollock-is-sir-hardin-thicke/recommended . The show is a production of "The Tapes Team" at SIRIUS, along with ''[[Stern Spotlight]]'', ''[[Mammary Lane]]'' and ''[[The History of Howard Stern]]''. ==See also== *[[Mammary Lane]] *[[Stern Spotlight]] *[[The History of Howard Stern]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.howard100channelguide.com/ Howard 100 Channel Guide] *[http://www.sirius.com/howard100 Sirius Howard 100] *[http://www.howardstern.com/ Howard Stern’s Official Website] *[http://www.sternfannetwork.com/ Stern Fan Network] *[http://www.siriusbackstage.com/forum/forumdisplay.php?f=34 Sirius Backstage's Howard Stern Forum] *[http://www.dawgsaloon.com/ DawgSaloon] {{Howard Stern Show}} [[Category:Sirius Satellite Radio]] [[Category:2006 radio programme debuts]] [[Category:Howard Stern]] {{US-radio-show-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Norway}} "Mitt liv" | image = [[File:Mitt_liv_1987.jpg|250px]] | caption = | year = 1987 | country = Norway | artist = [[Kate Gulbrandsen]] | as = | with = | language = Norwegian | languages = | composer = [[Rolf Løvland]] | lyricist = [[Rolf Løvland]], [[Hanne Krogh]] | conductor = Terje Fjærn | place = 9th | points = 65 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1987no from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Romeo | prev_link = Romeo (Ketil Stokkan song) | next = For vår jord | next_link = For vår jord }} '''"Mitt liv"''' ("My life") was the [[Norway|Norwegian]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1987]], performed in [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] by [[Kate Gulbrandsen]].
The song is a ballad, with Kate singing about her feelings towards her life. She sings that she needs to take responsibility for it, although she appears hesitant to do so.
The song was performed first on the night, preceding [[Israel]]'s [[Lazy Bums]] with "[[Shir Habatlanim]]". At the close of voting, it had received 65 points, placing 9th in a field of 22.
It was succeeded as [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest|Norwegian representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1988|1988 contest]] by [[Karoline Krüger]] with "[[For vår jord]]".
{{Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1987}}
[[Category:Eurovision songs of Norway]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1987]] [[Category:Songs written by Rolf Løvland]] [[Category:1987 songs]] [[Category:Mariann Grammofon singles]] [[Category:1987 singles]]
{{norway-stub}}

Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of Austria-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of Austria.svg|183|Austria Bundesadler.svg|115|The [[Flag of Austria]]|The [[Coat of arms of Austria]]}} [[File:LocationAustria.svg|thumb|The location of [[Austria]]]] [[File:Austria 1999 CIA map.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable relief map of the [[Republic of Austria]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Austria:
'''[[Austria]]''' – [[Landlocked country|landlocked]] [[List of sovereign states|sovereign country]] located in [[Central Europe]].<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 14, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/au.html|title=Austria|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref> It borders both [[Germany]] and the [[Czech Republic]] to the north, [[Slovakia]] and [[Hungary]] to the east, [[Slovenia]] and [[Italy]] to the south, and [[Switzerland]] and [[Liechtenstein]] to the west. The [[Capital (political)|capital]] is the city of [[Vienna]] on the [[Danube River]].<ref>CIA map 1</ref>
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== General reference == [[File:Oesterreich topo.png|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Austria]]]] * Pronunciation: {{IPAc-en|audio=en-us-Austria.ogg|ˈ|ɒ|s|t|r|i|ə}} or {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɔː|s|t|r|i|ə}} * Common English country name: [[Austria]] * Official English country name: The [[Republic of Austria]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Austrian (disambiguation)|Austrian]] <!-- This disambiguation page is the only page on Wikipedia that specifically explains this term and its country adjectival contexts, and it does so excellently. Please leave this link in place. --> * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Austria]] * [[ISO country codes]]: AT, AUT, 040 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:AT]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.at]]
== Geography of Austria == [[File:Austria satellite annotated.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable satellite map of [[Austria]]]] [[File:Großglockner from behind the glass panorama tower.JPG|thumb|[[Grossglockner]] is, at 3,798 metres above the Adriatic (12,461 ft), the highest mountain in Austria]] [[Image:Neusiedler See im Winter.jpg|thumb|[[Lake Neusiedl]], at 115 m (377 ft), the lowest point in Austria]] [[Geography of Austria]] * Austria is a: ** [[Country]] *** [[Developed country]] *** [[Landlocked country]] ** [[Sovereign state]] *** [[Member State of the European Union]] * Location: ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] and [[Eastern Hemisphere]] ** [[Eurasia]] *** [[Europe]] **** [[Central Europe]] **** [[Western Europe]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[Central European Time]] ([[UTC+01]]), [[Central European Summer Time]] ([[UTC+02]]) ** [[Extreme points of Austria]] *** High: [[Großglockner]] {{convert|3798|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Lake Neusiedl]] {{convert|115|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} Land boundaries: 2,562 km ::{{Flag|Germany}} 784 km ::{{Flag|Italy}} 430 km ::{{Flag|Hungary}} 366 km ::{{Flag|Czech Republic}} 362 km ::{{Flag|Slovenia}} 330 km ::{{Flag|Switzerland}} 164 km ::{{Flag|Slovakia}} 91 km ::{{Flag|Liechtenstein}} 35 km :*Coastline: ''none'' * [[Population of Austria]]: 8,316,487 people (2006 [[Approximation|estimate]]) - [[List of countries by population|93rd most populous country]] * [[Area of Austria]]: 83,872 km² (32,383 mi²) - [[List of countries and outlying territories by total area|115th largest country]] * [[:commons:Atlas of Austria|Atlas of Austria]]
=== Environment of Austria === [[File:GroßesWalsertal 01.JPG|thumb|[[Großwalsertal|The Great Walser Valley]]]] [[File:Lechquellengebirge1.jpg|thumb|The [[Untere Wildgrubenspitze]], the highest peak of the [[Lechquellen Mountains]] in Austria]] [[File:Poertschach Blick von Hoher Gloriette 11082013 344.jpg|thumb|[[Wörthersee]], Carinthia's largest lake]] [[Environment of Austria]] * [[Climate of Austria]] * [[Environmental issues in Austria]] * [[Renewable energy in Austria]] * [[Geology of Austria]] * [[Protected areas of Austria]] ** [[List of biosphere reserves in Austria|Biosphere reserves in Austria]] ** [[List of national parks of Austria|National parks of Austria]] * [[Wildlife of Austria]] ** [[Fauna of Austria]] *** [[List of birds of Austria|Birds of Austria]] *** [[List of mammals of Austria|Mammals of Austria]]
==== Natural geographic features of Austria ====
* [[Glaciers of Austria]] * [[List of lakes in Austria|Lakes of Austria]] * [[List of mountains in Austria|Mountains of Austria]] ** [[List of volcanoes in Austria|Volcanoes in Austria]] * [[List of rivers of Austria|Rivers of Austria]] ** [[List of waterfalls of Austria|Waterfalls of Austria]] * [[List of valleys of Austria|Valleys of Austria]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in Austria]]
==== Neighbors of Austria ==== [[File:Au-map.png|right|thumb|Map showing Austria and its neighbors]] Austria is bordered by: * [[Germany]] * [[Czech Republic]] * [[Slovakia]] * [[Hungary]] * [[Slovenia]] * [[Italy]] * [[Liechtenstein]] * [[Switzerland]]

{{Infobox Network | name = Radio Koper | logo = File:Radiokoper.jpg | country = {{SLO}} | network_type = [[Radio network]] | available = [[Slovenia]], [[Triveneto]] | owner = [[Radio-Television Slovenia]] | key_people = | launch_date = 1949 | past_names = | website = http://ava.rtvslo.si/predvajaj |}} ''' Radio Koper''' / '''Radio Capodistria''' is a radio station located in the city of [[Koper]], [[Slovenia]].It can be heard from [[Slovenia]] and northeastern part of [[Italy]] on the frequency of 103.1 MHz, 103.6 MHz and 97,7 MHz. Reception is possible on medium wave 1170 kHz in Slovenia, Croatia and North Italy.{{cite web |url=http://www.comunitaitalofona.org/dl/portali/site/articolo/ContentItem-cae2abea-a66f-4816-b0fe-414ff87325ae.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327234728/http://www.comunitaitalofona.org/dl/portali/site/articolo/ContentItem-cae2abea-a66f-4816-b0fe-414ff87325ae.html |archivedate=2014-03-27 |df= }} It is also available on the Satellite through Hot bird. [[Radio-Television Slovenia]] is the owner of the Radio. == History == Radio Koper was first heard on 24 May 1949, called '' Radio jugoslovanske cone Trsta - Radio Trieste zona Jugoslava'' (Radio Triest, Yugoslav Zone), and it started to broadcast a day later. It was owned by D. D. Radiofonia SA, set up by the then Yugoslav military administration Zone B of the former [[Free Territory of Trieste]]. After the abolition of the Free Territory in 1954, it teamed up with Radio Ljubljana and was later known as ''Radio Koper - Capodistria''. Until 1954, it broadcast programs in [[Slovene language|Slovenian]], [[Italian language|Italian]] and [[Croatian language|Croatian]]. From 1954 to 1979, the program was mainly in Italian, while two short blocks were reserved to Slovenian in the morning and evening time. In 1979, the two linguistic versions of the radio separated, each with its own transmitter network. Studio [[Nova Gorica]]] became operational in 1980, and in 1992 Radio Koper expanded into the Slovenian holding as an all-day radio broadcast. Radio Koper - Capodistria as a border and minority radio station played a very important role in the history of this area in bringing together neighboring nations, especially during the Cold War. For many years Radio Capodistria was one of the three most listened radio stations in Italy, its signal is stretched even to the shores of Africa, carrying Socialist and Titoist cross-border propaganda particularly appreciated by the members and sympathizers of the [[Italian Communist Party]], particularly its youth. After the independence of Slovenia, Radio Koper became an organizational unit of [[RTV Slovenia]], which has eliminated the transmission system in Italy, while the cross-border program shifted to minority and regional. == Programming and rating == Radio Koper is the most listened radio station in the [[Slovenian Littoral]] and on both sides of the Slovenian-Italian border. Many listeners also come from [[Croatian Istria]]. In 2011 it was among the ten most listened radio stations in Slovenia (official data radiometry carried out by the agency Mediapool). Radio Koper created a program that combines the informational, cultural, educational, children's, music, entertainment and sports programs. Its own program begins at 5:00 and ends at 24:00. During this time, the radio plays three regional news programs, five reports and a lot of voice and music broadcasts. During the night it broadcasts the night program of [[Radio Slovenija 1]], which it also prepares every Friday from the studios of Koper and Nova Gorica. In addition to regular programs, which are being prepared for all three programs, the contributions daily presence in news programming. Radio Koper is distinguished by its rich musical productions and is also establishing itself as a promoter of cultural and social events throughout the coastal region, including that in Italy, where Slovenians live. == Infrastructures == The Hendrix Studio of Radio Koper is designed for the recording and production of classical, choral and pop music. It is used for the most demanding technical music radio shows, roundtables and confrontation. It is a technologically modern music production studio, which for many years has been famous for its excellent acoustic characteristics such as the recording control box. Radio Koper's ''Fonoteka'' keeps the archives of music and recordings from the beginning of broadcasting of the Slovenian and Italian program on different media. On the shelves is also has over 25,000 strips, 44,000 LPs, CDs 22100, 2000 CD-house production - recorded in the studio Hendrix and beyond 1100 DAT tapes. At present, the entire archive is in the process of digitization. Radio Koper also has a contemporary reportage truck RA 3, equipped with the most modern digital technology, which allows the sound recordings of musical events and transfers of technology-intensive events at external locations. File:Studio 02.JPG|Studio 02 Radio Koper, from there live broadcasts are conducted File:Fonoteka.jpg| Panels in the Fonoteka Radio Koper File:Radio Koper - reportažno vozilo RA3.jpg|Contemporary reportage truck RA 3 File:SMS na plaži.JPG|Charts Fresh blue selection at the beach Lighthouse in [[Izola]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.rtvslo.si/modload.php?&c_mod=rtvoddajeradio&c_menu=5 Website] {{sl icon}} {{en icon}} {{de icon}} *{{commons category-inline|Radio Koper}}

{{Infobox rail line | box_width = | name = Standseilbahn Kriens–Sonnenberg | color = | logo = | logo_width = | image = 100804 Sonnenbergbahn-im-Bahnhof.jpg | image_width = 250px | caption = | type = | system = | status = | locale = | start = [[Kriens]] | end = [[Sonnenberg (Kriens)|Sonnenberg]] | stations = 3 | routes = | daily_ridership = | open = 1902 | close = | owner = | operator = | character = | depot = | stock = | linelength = | tracklength = {{convert|839|m}} | tracks = | gauge = {{RailGauge|1000mm}} | minradius = | electrification = | maxincline = | racksystem = | speed = | elevation = | map = | map_state = }} [[File:AG Sonnenbergbahn 1901.jpg|thumb|Share of the AG Sonnenbergbahn, issued 8. August 1901]] The '''Sonnenberg Funicular''', also known as the '''''Standseilbahn Kriens–Sonnenberg''''' (KSB) or '''''Sonnenbergbahn''''', is a [[funicular railway]] near the [[Lucerne|city of Lucerne]] in the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[canton of Lucerne]]. It links the [[Kriens|town of Kriens]] with the [[Sonnenberg (Kriens)|Sonnenberg]], a hiking and recreational area, and serves an intermediate stop at Zumhof.{{cite web | url = http://www.seetal-plus.ch/Tourismus/Sonnenberg.html | title = Sonnenberg-Bahn, Kriens | work = Seetal-plus.ch | accessdate = 2014-04-17}}{{cite web | url = http://www.seilbahninventar.ch/objekt.php?objid=40372&lang=de | title = 61.044 Kriens - Sonnenberg, Kriens, Standseilbahn | language = German | work = Swiss Inventory of Ropeways | publisher = Swiss Confederation | accessdate = 2014-04-17}} The line was opened in 1902. In recent years it has been restored electrically and mechanically. The funicular has the following parameters: {| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse; font-size:95%; margin-right:10px; margin-bottom:5px;" |- |Number of stops |3 |- |Configuration |[[Single track (rail)|Single track]] with [[passing loop]] |- |Track length |{{convert|839|m|0}} |- |Rise |{{convert|210|m}} |- |Maximum [[Grade (slope)|gradient]] |42.5% |- |Track gauge |{{RailGauge|1000mm|allk=on}} |- |Number of cars |2 |- |Capacity |30 passengers per car |- | Maximum speed | {{convert|1.6|m/s}} |- | Travel time | 8 minutes |- |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{commonscat-inline|Sonnenbergbahn|Kriens–Sonnenberg funicular}}

'''Supreme commander''' is a title given to a person who controls and runs a [[militant]], [[insurgent]] or [[List of designated terrorist organizations|terrorist organization]], especially in [[South Asia]].
The title is often used for the head of a supreme council in many organizations, such as [[Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan|Tehrik-i-Taliban]].<ref name=siddiqa>{{cite journal | title = Pakistan's Counterterrorism Strategy: Separating Friends from Enemies | journal = The Washington Quarterly | year = 2011 | first = Ayesha | last = Siddiqa | volume = 34 | issue = 1 | pages = 149–162| doi = 10.1080/0163660X.2011.53836 | url = http://www.twq.com/11winter/docs/11winter_Siddiqa.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =7 November 2013 | ref = harv}}</ref> <ref name=CNNdead>{{cite news |title=Sources: Pakistani Taliban leader is dead |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/02/09/pakistan.meshud.dead/ |work=CNN |date=9 February 2010 |accessdate=7 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="Afghan Taliban Opration Against TTP">{{cite web | url=http://www.terminalx.org/2013/06/afghan-taliban-decide-to-boot-out-ttp-from-afghanistan.html | title=Afghan Taliban decide to boot out the TTP from Afghanistan | publisher=http://www.terminalx.org | accessdate=7 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="TTP new chief">{{cite web | url=http://www.firstpost.com/world/tehrik-e-taliban-pakistan-elects-new-chief-1208337.html | title=Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan elects new chief | publisher=http://www.firstpost.com | accessdate=7 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="Mullah Baradar Released From Pakistani Prison">{{cite web | url=http://www.tolonews.com/en/afghanistan/12003-update-mullah-baradar-released-from-pakistani-prison-hpc-welcomes-move | title=Mullah Baradar Released From Pakistani Prison, HPC Welcomes Move | publisher=http://www.tolonews.com | accessdate=7 November 2013}}</ref><ref name="Members of Taliban's 'supreme command' arrested in Pakistan">{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/pakistan/7264988/Members-of-Talibans-supreme-command-arrested-in-Pakistan-raids.html | title=Members of Taliban's 'supreme command' arrested in Pakistan raids | work=https://www.telegraph.co.uk | accessdate=7 November 2013}}</ref>
<!-- '' (1) The relevance of the following is unclear, if there is any relevance. (2) "Supreme Commander" was a title more often used for a general/admiral heading a joint Allied command.'' ==Nazi Germany== The phrase "Supreme Leader", as ''Oberste Führer'', was used by [[Adolf Hitler]] in his role respectively as supreme commander of the ''[[Sturmabteilung]]'' (SA) and the ''[[Schutzstaffel]]'' (SS). Hitler's supreme commander titles were considered [[paramilitary]], and were the top tiers amongst several [[Nazi party paramilitary ranks]]. -->

{{unreferenced|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Norway}} "The First Day of Love" | image = [[File:The_First_Day_of_Love.jpg|250 px]] | caption = | year = 1974 | country = Norway | artist = Anne Karine Strøm | as = | with = | language = English | languages = | composer = [[Frode Thingnæs]] | lyricist = Philip A. Kruse | conductor = [[Frode Thingnæs]] | place = 14th | points = 3 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1974no from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = It's Just A Game | prev_link = It's Just A Game | next = Touch My Life (With Summer) | next_link = Touch My Life (With Summer) }} '''"The First Day of Love"''' ({{lang-no|"Den første dagen av kjærlighet"|italic=no}}) was the [[Norway|Norwegian]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1974]], performed in [[English language|English]] by [[Anne-Karine Strøm]]. This was the first occasion on which the Norwegian entry had not featured any lyrics in [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]].
The song is an inspirational number, with Anne Karine singing about the regenerative power of love. She sings that everyone in the world wants the same thing, love, and that by moving towards that goal the human race is becoming closer.
The song was performed fourth on the night, following [[Spain]]'s [[Peret]] with "[[Canta y sé feliz]]" and preceding [[Greece]]'s [[Marinella]] with "[[Krasi, Thalasa Ke T' Agori Mu]]". At the close of voting, it had received just 3 points and perhaps unjustly, the song came last, placing joint 14th in a field of 17.
In the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1976|1976 contest]], Anne Karine Strøm would represent Norway for the third and final time with the disco oriented song "[[Mata Hari (song)|Mata Hari]]", she would finish with 7 points, and 18th out of 18 entrants, thus awarding Strøm the unique accolade of being the only performer in history of the Eurovision Song Contest, to have finished in last place more than once, a record she still holds as of 2012.
Anne was succeeded as [[Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest|Norwegian representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1975|1975 contest]] by fellow Bendik Singer [[Ellen Nikolaysen]] with "[[Touch My Life (With Summer)]]".
{{Norway in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1974}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Use British English|date=May 2017}} [[File:Visite du Branchage Juilet 2008 Saint Hélyi a.jpg|thumb|Measuring overhanging greenery with a pole of standard length]]
A '''Visite du Branchage''' is an inspection of roads in [[Jersey]] and [[Guernsey]] to ensure property owners have complied with the laws against vegetation encroaching onto the road.
==Jersey==
The Visite du Branchage takes place in each [[Parishes of Jersey|Parish]] twice a year to check that occupiers of houses and land bordering on public [[road]]s have undertaken the 'branchage'.
The ''Loi (1914) sur la Voirie'' imposes a duty on all occupiers of property to ensure that encroachments are removed from the public highway.
The first Visite is between 1–15 July and the second is between 1–15 September.
On the Visite du Branchage the [[Connétable (Jersey and Guernsey)|Connétable]], assisted by the members of the [[Roads Committee]], [[Roads Inspector]]s and the [[Centenier]]s, will visit the roads of his parish accompanied by the [[Vingtenier]]s in their respective [[Vingtaine]]s to ensure that the branchage has been completed. Occupiers of land may be fined up to £50 for each infraction unless - *the 'branchage' [hedges, branches and overhanging trees] has been trimmed back so as to give a clearance of 12 feet over main roads and by-roads; *the 'branchage' [hedges, branches and overhanging trees] has been trimmed back so as to give a clearance of 8 feet over [[Sidewalk|footpath]]s; and all trimmings have been removed from the road.
If the branchage has not been completed the occupier will be required to undertake the work and, if it is not carried out, the Parish may arrange for the work to be done and charge the occupier the cost of that work.
The Visite du Branchage applies to all public roads including main roads, by-roads and footpaths.
The [[Branchage]] Film Festival, takes its name from Visite du Branchage. <gallery> Image:Visite du Branchage Juilet 2008 Saint Hélyi c.jpg|Members of the Roads Committee inspect an encroaching hedge Image:Visite du Branchage Juilet 2008 Saint Hélyi b.jpg|A Vingtenier draws up any charges Image:Visite du Branchage Juilet 2008 Saint Hélyi d.jpg|A tree is measured for encroachment over the footway and the roadway </gallery>
==References== <references/>

{{Infobox radio station | name = WJTP | image = | city = [[Lithia Springs, Georgia|Lithia Springs]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | area = [[Atlanta metro area]] | branding = | slogan = | airdate = April 15, 1959{{cite web|url=https://licensing.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/prod/cdbs/forms/prod/getimportletter_exh.cgi?import_letter_id=53168 |title=History cards of WJTP}} | frequency = 890 [[kHz]] ([[Amplitude modulation|AM]]) | format = simulcast of [[China Radio International]] | power = 5,000 [[watt]]s day | erp = | haat = | class = D | facility_id = 2464 | coordinates = {{coord|33|45|39.00|N|84|28|42.00|W|region:US_type:city}} | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = WGOG (1959-2002)
WSSW (2002)
WSMW (2002-2003)
WWOF (2003-2008) | former_frequencies = 1460 kHz (1959-1965)
1000 kHz (1965-2008) | owner = James Su | licensee = Major Radio, LLC | sister_stations = | webcast = [http://68.168.103.13:8357/listen.pls Listen Live] | website = | affiliations = [[China Radio International]] }} '''WJTP''' is an [[AM broadcasting|AM]] [[radio station]] broadcasting on a frequency of 890 [[kHz]] with 5,000 [[watt]]s of power during daytime hours only. The [[radio station|station]] is licensed to [[Lithia Springs, Georgia]], a suburb of [[Atlanta metropolitan area|Atlanta]]. Its signal is transmitted from a facility closer to the city of [[Atlanta, Georgia]] as it shares the broadcast towers of [[WAOK (AM)|WAOK]] AM 1380 near the western interchange of [[Interstate 20 in Georgia|Interstate 20]] and [[Interstate 285 (Georgia)|Interstate 285]]. The station is currently owned by James Su.{{cite web|url=http://www.fcc.gov/fcc-bin/amq?call=WJTP |title=WJTP Facility Record |work=United States [[Federal Communications Commission]], audio division }} Because WJTP shares the same frequency as "[[clear-channel station|clear channel]]" station [[WLS (AM)|WLS]] AM 890 in [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]], this station only broadcasts during the [[daytime (astronomy)|daytime]] hours. ==History== ===Origins=== '''WJTP''' was established on April 15, 1959, as '''WGOG''', broadcasting from [[Walhalla, South Carolina]] at 1460 kHz.{{cite web|url=https://licensing.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/prod/cdbs/forms/prod/getimportletter_exh.cgi?import_letter_id=53168 |title=History cards of WJTP}} WGOG was owned by Oconee Broadcasting. On June 16, 1965, WGOG switched its frequency to 1000 kHz (a frequency used for clear channel radio). In 1984, Oconee Broadcasting sold WGOG to Luzanne Griffith, who was the station's Traffic Manager and Receptionist. Ms. Griffith would establish WGOG-FM in 1991. On April 1, 2002, WGOG was sold to Georgia-Carolina Radiocasting, changing its callsign to '''WSSW'''. On April 18, 2002, the station changed its call sign to '''WSMW'''. Then, on September 25, 2003, it changed to '''WWOF'''. ===Move to Atlanta=== On June 26, 2008, Tugart Properties, LLC sold WWOF to New Life Broadcasting and was cleared to move into the [[Atlanta metropolitan area|Atlanta market area]] on its new frequency 890 [[kHz]]. On October 10, 2008, WWOF changed to the current WJTP.{{cite web|url=http://fjallfoss.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/ws.exe/prod/cdbs/pubacc/prod/call_hist.pl?Facility_id=2464&Callsign=WJTP |title=WJTP Call Sign History |work=United States [[Federal Communications Commission]], audio division }} The station began broadcasting from its new facility in [[Lithia Springs, Georgia]] on January 25, 2009, with a Spanish Christian format. In January 2011, the station began simulcasting China Radio International, broadcasting general news and entertainment in English and Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese), targeting Chinese-Americans in the Atlanta area. Programs from CRI are distributed by AIM Broadcasting (American International Media) in Palo Alto, California. China Radio International also airs over [[KGBC]] 1540 AM in the [[Houston, Texas]] area. On June 30, 2012, the station's license was transferred from New Life Broadcasting to National Broadcasting, Inc. The two companies share common ownership. In October 2013, WJTP was sold to James Su's Major Radio, LLC for $2.1 million. The sale was consummated on December 23, 2013. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{AM station data|WJTP}} {{Atlanta AM}} {{China Radio International}} {{Daytime-only radio stations in Georgia}} [[Category:Radio stations in Atlanta|JTP]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1959]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:China Radio International]] [[Category:Daytime-only radio stations]]

{{Use dmy|date=July 2015}} [[File:Weimar Triangle.png|thumb|350px|Political map of the "Weimar Triangle"]] The '''"Weimar Triangle"''' is, loosely, a grouping of [[Poland]], [[Germany]], and [[France]]. The group is intended to promote co-operation between the three countries in crisis zones.<ref name="eubusiness"/> It exists mostly in the form of [[Summit (meeting)|summit meetings]] between the leaders of these three countries, the most recent of which occurred on 7 February 2011.<ref>[http://www.thenews.pl/business/?id=148874 "Leaders in Warsaw can’t cover up EU budget rift"] Thenews.pl, News from Poland. Retrieved 7 February 2011.</ref> Previous meetings took place in [[Poznań]], Poland (1998), [[Nancy, France|Nancy]], France (1999), [[Hambach, Germany|Hambach]], Germany (2001) and Nancy, France (2005). The Weimar Triangle also involves lower-level connections, such as the annual meeting between [[Foreign minister|Foreign Ministers]].
The most recent leaders' summit was hosted by President [[Bronisław Komorowski]] of Poland and attended by President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] (France) and Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] (Germany). Issues of renewing regular Weimar Triangle meetings, the Egyptian situation and improving relations with Russia were discussed (Among other topics). Both Germany and France urged Poland to join the pact for competitiveness.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
== History == [[File:Weimar Battlegroup.jpg|thumb|200px|Emblem of the [[Weimar Battlegroup]].]] The Weimar Triangle was established in the German city of [[Weimar]] in 1991, aimed at assisting Poland's emergence from [[Communism|Communist]] rule. Attending the meeting were the Foreign Ministers of each state: [[Roland Dumas]] of France, [[Hans-Dietrich Genscher]] of Germany, and [[Krzysztof Skubiszewski]] of Poland.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} Genscher chose Weimar for the inaugural meeting because it was situated in former East Germany.<ref name="independent.co.uk">Sarah Helm (May 23, 1996), [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/weimar-triangle-takes-shape-for-power-1348723.html 'Weimar Triangle' takes shape for power] ''[[The Independent]]''.</ref>
At the 1992 meeting of the Weimar Triangle in France, Poland won agreement from Germany and France that it should have special association status at the [[Western European Union]], the European arm of [[NATO]].<ref name="independent.co.uk"/>
On 5 July 2011, Poland, France, and Germany signed an agreement in Brussels to put together a unit of 1,700 soldiers, called the [[Weimar Battlegroup]], that will be ready to deploy in crisis zones starting in 2013. The EU business newsletter reports that Poland will command the group, providing the core combat troops and a mechanised battalion, Germany will provide logistical support, and France will contribute medical support. The operational command centre will be based in Mont Valerien, located in a Paris suburb.<ref name="eubusiness">AFP, [http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/military-france.b52 Germany, France and Poland form EU battlegroup] EUbusiness. Retrieved 5 July 2011.</ref>
Shortly after the [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|referendum]] on the status of [[Crimea]] held on March 16, 2014, the chairpersons of the Weimar Triangle parliaments's committees on foreign affairs – [[Elisabeth Guigou]] of [[France]], [[Norbert Röttgen]] of [[Germany]] and [[Grzegorz Schetyna]] of [[Poland]] – visited Kyiv to express their countries’ firm support of the territorial integrity and the European integration of [[Ukraine]].<ref>[http://mfa.gov.ua/en/press-center/news/21506-krajini-vejmarsykogo-trikutnika-pidtrimujuty-teritorialynu-cilisnisty-ta-jevrointegracijnij-postup-ukrajini Weimar Triangle countries support the territorial integrity and European integration of Ukraine] [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Ukraine)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine]], press release of April 11, 2014.</ref> This was the first time that parliamentarians of the Weimar Triangle had ever made a joint trip to a third country.<ref>[https://www.bundestag.de/presse/pressemitteilungen/2014/pm_1404081/263198 Parlamentarier des Weimarer Dreiecks: Röttgen, Guigou und Schetyna in Kiew] [[Bundestag]], press release of April 8, 2014.</ref>
In April 2016, Poland's foreign minister [[Witold Waszczykowski]] told daily newspaper ''[[Gazeta Wyborcza]]'' that the Weimar Triangle had lost its relevance for his country.<ref>Matthias Szczerbaniewicz (April 6, 2016), [http://www.heute.de/polen-haelt-weimarer-dreieck-mit-deutschland-und-frankreich-fuer-erschoepft-42988830.html "Weimarer Dreieck" beendet: Polens Abkehr vom alten Europa] ''[[ZDF]]''.</ref>
On 28 August 2016, representatives of the three countries vowed to "reinvigorate" the Weimar Triangle. German foreign minister [[Frank-Walter Steinmeier]] said the group would meet before the end of 2016, and French foreign minister [[Jean-Marc Ayrault]] said France would host a summit in November 2016. The stated reasoning for this reinvigoration were the [[Brexit|decision of the United Kingdom to leave the European Union]], as well as the ongoing [[European migrant crisis]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Shalal|first1=Andrea|title=Germany, Poland and France revive Weimar group to bolster EU confidence|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-britain-germany-weimar-idUSKCN1130S7|website=Reuters|accessdate=28 August 2016|location=Weimar, Germany|language=English|date=28 August 2016}}</ref>

==Summits of heads of state== # 21 September 1993 in [[Gdańsk]], Poland # 21 February 1998 in [[Poznań]], Poland # 7 May 1999 in [[Nancy, France|Nancy]], France # 27 February 2001 in [[Hambach, Germany|Hambach]], Germany. # 9 May 2003 in [[Wrocław]], Poland. Summit on 3 July 2006 in Weimar, Germany was postponed due to alleged indisposition of the Polish president [[Lech Kaczyński]].
==Summits of Defence Ministers== # 25 July 2006 in [[Wieliczka]], Poland # 18 December 2007 in [[Berlin]], Germany
In March 2015, Germany's [[Federal Ministry of Defence (Germany)|Minister of Defence]] [[Ursula von der Leyen]] hosted her counterparts [[Jean-Yves Le Drian]] of [[France]] and [[Tomasz Siemoniak]] of [[Poland]] to revive a meeting format intended to promote co-operation between the three countries in crisis zones; it was the first meeting between the Weimar Triangle defence ministers since 2007.<ref>[http://www.thenews.pl/1/10/Artykul/201980,MoD-Siemoniak-EU-needs-new-security-strategy MoD Siemoniak: EU needs new security strategy] ''[[Polskie Radio]]'', March 31, 2015.</ref>
